body: Current temp fix is to use declare them in your own code and then use /FORCE:MULTIPLE to allow multiple declarations.

Thanks for the reply.

According to the article I referenced, you can write a dummy function to force the .lib to always get linked in. 

If it isn't fixed, then I think having the NvOptimusEnablement stuff in there is misleading as it is only exported for /subsystem:windows builds. Maybe it could be somewhere else.

> According to the article I referenced, you can write a dummy function to force the .lib to always get linked in.

You could actually use `NvOptimusEnablement` in your code to achieve this. But I think the cleaner option would still be to implement the export and `WinMain` yourself.

> If it isn't fixed, then I think having the NvOptimusEnablement stuff in there is misleading as it is only exported for /subsystem:windows builds. Maybe it could be somewhere else.

It is somewhat. Unfortunately there's no other part of SFML that's always linked statically. It won't work as an export in a dll file. It has to happen in the executable itself. All solutions of a hidden use result in code you'd have to manually add either way.

---

As an alternative, did you consider allocating/attaching a console window on your own in a (I guess) Win32 debug build? So you'd always use `/SUBSYSTEM:WINDOWS` and [then add the console window](http://stackoverflow.com/questions/24399174/how-to-add-console-window-in-win32-project-visual-studio-2010). This way you could even make it a toggle or command line switch.
SFML could fix this using `#pragma comment(linker, "/include:XXX" )`

Haven't tried that yet. This sounds like a good idea, but then we'd force people into using **sfml-main**, even if they'd like to write or use their own wrapper code, e.g. to do exception handling. Not really sold on that one.

> According to the article I referenced, you can write a dummy function to force the .lib to always get linked in.

I read the article, but didn't fully understand how this would be done. They say there needs to be a reference to that dummy function, so we'd have to call it from outside, which seems impossible as there's no explicit dependency on sfml-main.

One point that hasn't been mentioned here is that SFML doesn't guarantee, that the dedicated GPU will be used. The introduced exports are mostly a convenience and since pretty much all final releases don't use a console attached to the game, it's a convenience that works most of the time.

> One point that hasn't been mentioned here is that SFML doesn't guarantee, that the dedicated GPU will be used. The introduced exports are mostly a convenience and since pretty much all final releases don't use a console attached to the game, it's a convenience that works most of the time.

Only when you're shipping, but I have spent 99% of the time testing my game with a console. Also be aware that games do ship with console sometimes, especially during Early Access / Beta. 

I suppose the least we could do is warn people that the symbols aren't exported in /SUBSYSTEM:CONSOLE mode. The best approach would be to make SFML responsible for exporting those symbols, but unfortunately it looks like it has to be in the main executable.

Another approach could be to just offer that code as a #define that the user can call in their application code. SFML_FORCE_HIGH_PERFORMANCE_GRAPHICS() or something, and then drop it in the tutorial/docs.

In any case, I think this issue will help future gamedevs, so it's good to get it all out there.

issue.title: Fix discrete GPU preference symbols being exported from the wrong place
issue.body:
Moved NvOptimusEnablement and AmdPowerXpressRequestHighPerformance out of sfml-main and into a macro the user can place in their own translation unit when they need it.

The current implementation suffers from a bunch of problems:
* It doesn't work when using the console subsystem, see #1192
* It can't work when linking all of SFML dynamically (this implies not linking sfml-main obviously)
* When linking sfml-main for portability, the user can't opt out of preferring the discrete GPU when they know they won't need the extra performance
* This "feature" was never documented, only people following the commit history or who browse through the code will know this exists
* Exporting symbols via `__declspec(dllexport)` from a static library is just weird in itself anyway

With this change, the user will have full control over when they want this preference to be made, and the symbols will always be exported from the right place: the final executable. And there is the added bonus that this will actually show up in the documentation as well (might still be hard to find though).
